Dear Ms. Taylor:
Attached is the Special Investigation Report for the above referenced facility. Due to the
violations identified in the report, a written corrective action plan is required. The
corrective action plan is due 15 days from the date of this letter and must include the
following:
• How compliance with each rule will be achieved.
• For any repeat violations, why the prior corrective action plan did not result
in compliance.
• Who is directly responsible for implementing the corrective action for each
violation.
• Specific time frames for each violation as to when the action steps will be
completed or implemented.
• How continuing compliance will be maintained once compliance is
achieved.
If you desire technical assistance in addressing these issues, please feel free to contact
me. In any event, the corrective action plan is due within 15 days. Failure to submit an
acceptable corrective action plan will result in disciplinary action.
Please review the enclosed documentation for accuracy and contact me with any
questions. In the event that I am not available, and you need to speak to someone
immediately, please contact the area manager, Jessica VandenHeuvel at 616-204-6992.

III. INVESTIGATION
Rule Code Sufficiency of staff.
Title
Rule Code & CCI Rule 400.4126
Section (1) The licensee shall have a sufficient number of administrative,
Description supervisory, social service, direct care, and other staff on duty to
perform the prescribed functions required by these administrative
rules and in the agency's program statement and to provide for the
continual needs, protection, and supervision of residents.
2

Violation Potential Rule or Statute Violation
Type
Allegation Within the last month, the lights in a unit were off. Two youth
engaged in sexual activity. The youth are in a relationship and
staff are aware. The two youth would turn the lights off and do
what they wanted to do including pushing beds together. It is
unknown why the youth have not been separated.
Investigation Interviews:
Supervisor Z was interviewed via telephone on October 10,
2024. Supervisor Z said Youth A and Youth B are “supposedly in a
relationship” and they got into an argument with Youth C so he
and Staff 1 took Youth C on a walk outside. Supervisor Z said
while on the walk Youth C said Youth A and Youth B are having
sexual contact and sexual intercourse. Supervisor Z said this was
the first time he had ever heard of this type of interaction occurring
between Youth A and Youth B. Supervisor Z said he has never
seen any sexual touching between Youth A and Youth B however
is aware that they have “bad boundaries” with one another and
many incident reports have been written about their boundaries.
Supervisor Z said Youth A and Youth B pushed their beds together
in an isle and have been sleeping like that for a while. Supervisor
Z said the staff have been struggling to get Youth A and Youth B to
follow directions and they will turn the lights off in the unit, refuse
to move their beds, and refuse to follow programming. Supervisor
Z said if it was up to him he would have separated the youth prior
to this investigation however stated it is up to the therapist, case
manager, and Director to make that decision.
Youth A was interviewed via telephone on October 2, 2024, in
collaboration with MDHHS worker. Youth A said she is currently
on unit five by herself, stating her peers were moved out of her
unit. Youth A said Youth B was moved off her unit and told it was
“best for her program”. Youth A said she is very upset about this
as she was “best friends” with Youth B, denying being in a
romantic relationship with her. Youth A said Youth C told Staff 1
that she and Youth B “did something inappropriate, like kiss or
something” which then led to the units being changed. Youth A
said Youth C reported it happened prior to September 12, 2024,
however she denied anything “like that” ever happening. Youth A
said Youth C is making these allegations because she is mad that
she and Youth B laughed at her for “doing stuff with the boys”.
Youth A said she and Youth B used to argue but over time they
started to get along much better and now they only interact with
each other and help each other get through the program. Youth A
said recently Youth B has helped her through the death of a
friend, and self-harming thoughts. Youth A said she, Youth B, and
3

Youth C all pushed their beds together in the same isle to make a
“king” size bed and slept that way for several nights. Youth A said
staff told them that was not allowed and redirected them to put the
beds back in their own isles however they did not listen. Youth A
said she always slept in the middle bed and Youth B and Youth C
were on either side of her. Youth A said they all had their own
bedding and were not under each other’s covers. Youth A said the
staff would always sit at the end of the isle and watch them all
night and denied anything physical or sexual ever occurring.
Youth A said the lights in the unit would be off but the “PREA
Light” in the middle of the unit was always on so the staff would be
able to see the youth all night. Youth A said Staff 1 as well as the
other staff were always supervising them throughout the night and
during the day. Youth A said she would hug Youth B as well as
many other people despite it being against the Vassar House
rules. Youth A said staff are always near her and Youth B, again
denying anything sexual ever occurred between her and Youth B.
Youth B was interviewed via telephone on October 2, 2024, in
collaboration with MDHHS worker. Youth B said she has been
placed at Vassar House for about eight months. Youth B said she
was in unit five until Monday at which time she was moved to unit
three however she does not know why. Youth B said she has
never had any relationship other than a friendship while placed at
Vassar House. Youth B denied any sexual interactions with Youth
A or any other youth while being placed at Vassar House. Youth B
said Youth C told Supervisor Z that she and Youth B had oral sex
and have been having sexual intercourse which is not true, stating
Youth C is only saying this because she is jealous of Youth A and
Youth B’s friendship. Youth B said she, Youth A, and Youth C all
pushed their beds together in September 2024. Youth B said they
were all “acting a fool” and just wanted to have a “sleepover”
knowing that it was against the rules and program. Youth B said
staff redirected the youth and told them to move the beds back to
their own spots, but the youth refused. Youth B said all of the staff
supervised them the entire time they had their beds together.
Youth B said they would all sleep in their own beds with their own
covers just all pushed together. Youth B denied getting into bed
with Youth A or Youth A getting into bed with her. Youth B said the
main lights would be off but the “PREA Light” is always on and it
gives enough light for staff to see the youth all night. Youth B said
Staff 1 has worked with her several times and she is a “wonderful
staff” that “cares about us girls”, and “keeps it real”. Youth B said
all of the staff were concerned about her and Youth A’s boundaries
and would sit in-between them or stand right by them to supervise.
Youth B said she and Youth A are “really close friends” and can
4

calm each other down, listen to what the other is going through,
and just understand one another. Youth B said the staff were doing
what they needed to do and she and Youth A “were not working
the program”.
Youth C was interviewed via telephone on October 23, 2024,
in collaboration with MDHHS worker. Youth C said Youth A and
Youth B are in a relationship and “everyone knows it”. Youth C
said she has witnessed Youth A and Youth B having sex, however,
would not elaborate on what she saw. Youth C said she also has
heard them having sex, again would not elaborate on what she
meant or heard. Youth C said it was in September 2024 when she
witnessed Youth A and Youth B having sex. Youth C said Staff 1
was working the unit and the lights were off. Youth C said at the
time Staff 1 was the only staff working because the other staff had
not arrived so the youth were to remain in bed so the ratio could
continue to be one to four. Youth C said Youth A and Youth B had
their beds pushed together in an isle. Youth C said she reported
what she saw to Staff 1 on a different day, stating she did not tell
her when it was occurring. Youth C said none of the youth are
allowed to physically touch one another and Youth A and Youth B
touch all the time. Youth C said staff redirect Youth A and Youth B
not to touch however they do not listen and staff then “do
paperwork on them”.
Youth D was not able to be interviewed. Youth D is no longer
placed at Vassar House and was moved back to her parental
home. On October 21, 2024, a phone call was made to Youth D’s
mother who refused to allow Youth D to be interviewed.
Staff 1 was interviewed face-to-face at the facility on October
7, 2024, by MDHHS worker, and via telephone by DCWL
Consultant on November 5, 2024. Staff 1 said she worked on
September 8, 2024, and was alone for the first hour or so due to
Staff 2 running late and the third shift staff refusing to stay for first
shift. Staff 1 said she kept the youth in their beds so ratio would
remain one to four until another staff arrived. Staff 1 said she sat
in the middle of the room and had line-of-sight of all youth except
for two times when she got up and opened the door for Supervisor
Y to enter. Staff 1 said each of those times was about 15 seconds.
Staff 1 said she has never seen Youth A and Youth B in the same
bed together however said they did have their beds pushed next
to each other in the same isle. Staff 1 said Youth A and Youth B
were still sleeping and she did not see them moving or touching
each other. Staff 1 said she has never seen Youth A and Youth B
sexually touching one another. Staff 1 said Vassar House program
5

does not allow the youth to touch each other in any way and Youth
A and Youth B would violate that rule and hug, touch arms, and do
each other’s hair. Staff 1 said staff would always redirect this
behaviors and document it on incident reports. Staff 1 said
Director would be the one to decide if and when a youth should
move to another unit. Staff 1 said it was not until she was out on a
walk with Youth C that she was informed of Youth A and Youth B
being sexual intercourse with one another.
Supervisor Y was interviewed via telephone on November 12,
2024. Supervisor Y said he does not remember walking into the
unit when Staff 1 was working however noted that he has been on
and off the units during the time he has worked at Vassar House.
Supervisor Y said there have been many times when he has seen
Youth A and Youth B with their beds pushed together and lying
next to each other under the same blankets. Supervisor Y said
staff had been directed to “get in the bed” with the youth, sit in a
chair at the end of the bed, and make them uncomfortable.
Supervisor Y said all staff have been aware that Youth A and
Youth B are in a relationship and have poor boundaries.
Supervisor Y said staff have written incident reports on the
boundary issues. Supervisor Y said Director is the one that makes
the decision to move the youth’s units. Supervisor Y denied ever
seeing sexual touching between Youth A and Youth B however
noted that they have been seen “laying on each other, holding
hands, hugging, sitting on each other’s laps”. Supervisor Y said he
and all staff he has witnessed have redirected this behavior
however Youth A and Youth B had no consequences for their
actions, so they ignored all redirection. Supervisor Y said Youth A
“runs the facility” and she is able to “do whatever she wants with
no consequences”.
Documents Reviewed:
• Youth A’s incident reports between August 27, 2024, and
September 30, 2024, regarding boundary issues with Youth
B. There are 38 incident reports for Youth A with various
boundary concerns from sitting on the bed, hugging,
following each other off the unit without permission,
entering the bathroom when Youth B was in there, and
eating food off Youth B’s plate.
• Youth B’s incident reports between August 31, 2024, and
September 29, 2024, regarding boundary issues with Youth
A. There are 21 incident reports for Youth A with various
boundary concerns from moving her bed into Youth A’s isle,
giving Youth A hugs, and inappropriate conversations.
6

• Staff 1’s personnel file: There was no disciplinary record
and Staff 1 completed the policy and procedure training
which includes supervision and line of sight on January 23,
2023.
Video Reviewed:
Video footage of September 8, 2024, unit five was reviewed on
October 30, 2024. Video footage is from 7:08am until 8:45am.
Staff 1 is sitting at a small table in the middle of the room
underneath a dim light. Two beds are pushed into one isle
however there is a gap between the beds. The staff is seen
getting up twice throughout the video, once to let someone in that
brings in breakfast, and once to get the food and bring it to the isle
that had two beds in it. Staff 1 does not have any lengthy period
where she is not supervising the isle with the two beds in it. At
8:44am the second staff arrives; lights are turned on and two
youth are seen getting out of bed.
Analysis The agency is found in compliance as per staff and youth
interviews and video review, Staff 1 supervised the youth as
required during the morning of September 8, 2024. In addition, the
staff have followed the policies and procedures, and redirected
Youth A and Youth B as required for boundary issues.
Conclusion Violation Not Established
Rule Code Staff to resident ratio
Title
Rule Code & CCI Rule 400.4127
Section (1) The licensee shall develop and adhere to a written staff-to-
Description resident ratio formula for direct care workers.
Violation Additional Findings of Non-Compliance
Type
Allegation Staff are not following the youth ratio formula outlined in the
agency program statement.
Investigation Interviews:
Youth C was interviewed via telephone on October 23, 2024,
in collaboration with MDHHS worker. Youth C said on the date
in which Youth A and Youth B had oral sex, Staff 1 was the only
staff working because the other staff had not arrived so the youth
were to remain in bed so they ratio could continue to be one to
four.
Staff 1 was interviewed face-to-face at the facility on October
7, 2024, by MDHHS worker, and via telephone by DCWL
7

Consultant on November 5, 2024. Staff 1 said she was trained
that as long as the youth are in their beds the ratio can be one to
four on the unit. Staff 1 said once the youth are “up and around”
the ratio is one to two. Staff 1 said she only has kept the youth in
their beds one time, on September 8, 2024, due to Staff 2 running
late for her shift.
Staff 3 was interviewed face-to-face at the facility on
November 14, 2024. Staff 3 said the “fall-in” time for youth to go
to bed is 9pm at which time the staff ratio changes to one to four.
Staff 3 said typically the youth then are woke up at 6am and the
ratio changes back to one to two. Staff 3 said if a first shift staff is
running late the third shift staff typically stay until they arrive,
however if they cannot stay the staff will call the supervisor and
they will come to the unit to work in ratio until the other staff
arrives. Staff 3 said if the third shift cannot stay, and the
supervisor is unable to be on the unit the staff will then continue to
let the youth sleep and any youth that is awake will have to remain
in bed until the other staff arrives. Staff 3 said this only occurs in
the morning and is not a normal occurrence.
Staff 4 was interviewed face-to-face at the facility on
November 14, 2024. Staff 4 said she works first shift and a few
second shifts. Staff 4 said the ratio is one to two during the day
and one to four at night. Staff 4 said the youth are not allowed out
of bed until there are two staff working the unit in the morning,
which is typically 6am. Staff 4 said there have been times when a
first shift staff is running late and so the other staff will just allow
the youth to remain asleep until the second staff arrives. Staff 4
said she has never seen the youth placed back into their beds
during the day shifts for ratio purposes.
Staff 5 was interviewed face-to-face at the facility on
November 14, 2024. Staff 5 said she typically works first shift and
has worked some second shifts. Staff 5 said the ratio is one to two
during the day and one to four at night. Staff 5 said first shift is
scheduled to arrive at 6am at which time the ratio changes from
one to four to one to two. Staff 5 said if someone is running late
the staff let the supervisor know and then leave the lights off and
let the youth remain asleep until the second staff arrives. Staff 5
said she has never heard or seen anyone have the youth go to
their beds throughout the shifts to change the ratio, stating the
ratio would still be one to two since the youth are all awake.
Documents Reviewed:
8

Vassar House Program Statement dated November 6, 2023, was
reviewed. The program statement said the “Staff to Client ratio is 1
to 2 clients.”
Analysis The agency is found in non-compliance as per the staff and youth
interviews, the staff work one staff to four youth at night and there
have been times when the first shift staff is running late, and the
youth are required to remain in bed until the second staff arrives.
TECHNICAL ASSISTANCE:
Technical assistance was offered to create a policy outlining
sleeping and awake hours to ensure clear ratio expectations.
Ratio is not to be contingent on when a staff arrive or leave work.
Conclusion Violation Established
IV. RECOMMENDATION
Based on investigative findings the facility is not in compliance with all applicable
licensing statutes and rules. Upon receipt of an acceptable corrective action plan, it
is recommended that the current license status be continued.
